posts.content:
I jest only because of what Graham said.
Where is Dave based? He's obviously a very well respected guy.
I do not know what Dave is on...but it must must be time shifting not mind shifting...

When I worked in Japan...I was fascinated by Manga giffs and searched for ages to get the most frames in the smallest file size to use as an avatar...
I have several but this one is amazing.....I never tire from watching it...
I was tempted to put another one on but worried this might fail the file size so resisted!

My sons laugh at it too.
Seabass = 35
Nexus 7 = 30

LOL

Dave promised to have this one ready for my son's wedding at the end of May..
I cannot see him letting my son down...
He promised..
Or was it for the first born...or the second born..

But I jest, Excellent work takes time..

Still not reading are you Dave!
LOL

Following Dave's good advice and using my better judgement (and not my Scotsman mean approach) over ruled by the desire to do the right thing...the logic of buying an Autocraft inner panel is now plain to see.
The panels can all be referenced to something which forms the front end relationship..
Lower valence panels to lower A post assembly to inner panel.
Positioned clamped and tack welded when needed so it can all be adjusted till perfect..
Dave says he is running out of clamps ===all are in use on Sherry..

Most of the NS of the bus was held together with pop rivets..The panels used were VW replacement panels..even found the OG VW labels on them!
Should have called it BITZA..



Now you can see the logic of Dave's methodology, restore and re-panel the cab and cargo doors first so you can use them as the reference shapes to fill the holes. Then you can true the A post, B post and C post to set the gaps as it all comes back together..

On this side the KF27 is trued to the lower valance panels and the inner panel.
I bought the Klassicfab complete assembly with the lower A post panels all assembled.
Dave has trued and cleaned off the funky green paint to get the panels lined up..
Yet more clamps...



Matt/Dave had cut out the cab floor end and tidied the chassis already. Chassis ends repaired to mate to the inner panel and lower valence. A post spot welded to inner panel.
Dash support by a piece of box section tube.

All very flexible still.
The rotten end to the dash has been tidied up but leaves a gap to the A post..
All looking really good...coming together..



Doors rehung on the restored door hinges using nice new machine screws and 8.5mm OS mirror arms and lower pins..
Dave is going to hate me when I want that shiny Stainless steel painting yet again! LOL

So coming along really nicely..
Soon be time for the topping off ceremony!

Oh oh Dave has been reading.....

"Yep, been reading, lurking, watching : )
More pics in the morning "

Love it Dave...
You explain what you will do and then just do it!
Really pleased!

type21f wrote:

Doors rehung on the restored door hinges using nice new machine screws and 8.5mm OS mirror arms and lower pins..
Dave is going to hate me when I want that shiny Stainless steel painting yet again! LOL



So… the restoring of hinges. Is it just a case of drilling out to the first oversize i.e. 8.5mm from the original 8mm? It's a job I have to do at some point - I've been using a screwdriver shank thus far

End of May though…… gotta go some

...and Matt too...
Sorry!
Both do cut n shut, weld and assembly...

Matt is Maestro Mechanical & Electrical fit out man M&E supremo! His electics, cable runs, pipe runs are a thing to behold..

Dave is prep n paint Maestro- how's the arms from blocking Dave? LOL LOL

They both will try anything..
I like the way I draw pictures, write desciptions, do schematics and they have the skils to do what I dream of..
Nice meek and very very capable guys!
Cheers..
Sherry is in good hands!

I have a dream...
Sadly the new up n coming outlaw has better friends than me..
I proposed Peebles for the wedding car...but new MIL has "friends" ...
Her "friend" is providing a 1952 convertible Bentley...


I have to admit it is very nice....

BUT result...
Peebles will still be needed ......to carry the bridesmaids...

RESULT

but who will volunteer to drive...
ME ME ME
yes...to cure dropped hinges...drill ream hinge arms to 8.5mm and fit replacement arms and pins

Teaser

....as the words of the song says...
"Everyone's gone to the moon...."





Yipppeee... Topping off ceremony..

Pictures look Hilarious...
Roof including air box and peak and vents have been prepped...and painted with beige grey.
Whilst the rest of the bus below is full of holes...

Hilarious..

Dave has formers for the shape and depth of the windscreen apertures..so he adjust the aperture to be mm perfect.
Cab doors mounted on correct/ OS 8.5mm size hinge pins with hinges bolted in position allows this to be all trimmed and set.
With the stripped down "new" cab door tops mounted in position..this allows A post and B post to be set at height to roof and gaps to be set at top and sides. Inner wheel arch can be welded in position to match the bottom.

The fun will be getting the long side parrallel to the edge of the roof gutter - pushing it out and in till it looks straight down the gutter.
Because Dave/ Matt have taken off the inner skin it is real flexible...

oooooooh .... I am excited...

More pictures to come.

I am that excited I am off to look in my favourite Material shop again for some '60s fabrics for Devons..
At the moment I am going with a Red Toile du Juoy from Sanderson...with Parrots on just like a red version of the curtains on the 63 Devonette brochure...
I have 10m of Red with black in background Duracouresque upholstery fabric for the seats..
Still trying to interpret one photo from the 63 brochure..
Think i will post a "Say what you see..." quiz to get other opinions on how the interior worked..
Cannot find any period pics..
Keep asking..
G

I have received more pictures from Dave...I am presently abroad... leaving my wife in England.. I'm here to see Scotland v Italy!

LOL

So Dave n Matt have enroled for the Magic Circle..

Rotten roof
I see no roof...
Roof!


But it looks like it was always there....










Next to start on short side and C pillar?
